item.title: Beef Stew Recipe
item.description:
I made a beef stew today. I didn't expect it would turn out to be so delicious. Take a look a the photos below.

Ingredients

  • olive oil
  • 0.3kg beef strips
  • 2 mid-sized onions
  • 1 .33cl bottle of Murphy's Irish Red
  • 1 tomato

Spices

  • salt
  • pepper
  • basil
  • red paprika (it would be even better if it was smoked paprika)
  • a couple of chili peppers

Procedure

I put the two sliced onions on a preheated pan with olive oil and added salt. When they turned yellow, I put the meat on top and closed the pan. Shortly there after I also put one sliced tomato on top of everything and let everything boil a little.

Once I was sure the meat was cooked I put in all of the above mentioned spices. I don't remember the exact ratio as I used my taste to guide me.

Just before the whole sauce evaporated I poured in around 0.15cl of Irish Red and let it cook a few minutes more.

And that's it!

item.title: Amsterdam on Saturday
item.description:
I went for a walk with my camera today. It was a really warm sunny day. Hopefully there will be more days like this this fall...

From Wikipedia:

The Munttoren ("Coin Tower") or Munt is a tower in Amsterdam, the Netherlands. It stands on the busy Muntplein square, where the Amstel river and the Singel canal meet, near the flower market and the eastern end of the Kalverstraat shopping street.

The tower was originally part of the Regulierspoort, one of the main gates in Amsterdam's medieval city wall. The gate, built in the years 1480, consisted of two towers and a guard house.

They have all kinds of beers here :)

item.title: How to batch resize images and add watermarks
item.description:
I've been an ImageMagick user for a long time. As the web site says:

ImageMagick® is a software suite to create, edit, compose, or convert bitmap images. It can read and write images in a variety of formats (over 100) including DPX, EXR, GIF, JPEG, JPEG-2000, PDF, PNG, Postscript, SVG, and TIFF. Use ImageMagick to resize, flip, mirror, rotate, distort, shear and transform images, adjust image colors, apply various special effects, or draw text, lines, polygons, ellipses and Bézier curves.

This is the basic comand I use to resize a single image:

convert source.png -resize x720 output.png

It takes the source.png, resizes it's height to 720px, keeps the proportions, and saves it as output.png. You could also specify the desired width instead of height with 1280x, or specific dimensions with 1280x720.

If I wanted to do the same for all images in the current directory, I would make use of the find command:

mkdir resized  
find *.png -exec convert {} -resize x720 resized/{} \;

This will convert all png files in the current directory and output them to the resized/ subdirectory. The \; part is a delimiter which tells find where is the end of the command to execute.

To add the watermark to the bottom-right corner of an image you can use:

composite -gravity southeast -geometry +10+10 watermark.png source.png output.png

To resize the image and automatically add the watermark:

convert source.png -resize x720 miff:- | composite -gravity southeast -geometry +10+10 watermark.png miff:- output.png

Here we made use of the miff, ImageMagick's intermediary file format which enables image pipelining between multiple commands.

It's a bit more complicated to do pipes with the find command, so I created a bash script which does that:

The basic syntax is:

resize.sh <source image> <dimensions> <destination folder>

So to automatically scale the height of all images in current folder to 720px, keep their proportions, and add watermarks we can use:

mkdir watermarked/  
find *.png -exec /path/to/resize.sh {} x720 watermarked/ \;

item.title: "Do you know of any XYZ developers?"
item.description:
One of the first things I noticed when I moved to Amsterdam was that there is a lot of businesses going on. A lot more than in my home country.

Just a week before I moved here, I was offered an interview for a senior position at Booking.com. When I said was already coming there next week, but for another job, I was asked if I can recommend anybody else. They seemed desperate to find somebody.

The first thing on my To Do list was to find a gym nearby where I could weightlift after work. During the first few visits I met a guy who worked for another start-up. He said they are constantly looking for developers.

A few days ago I met a tourist from Paris who owns a French startup. As soon as he realized I do software, he said they are looking for good JavaScript developers and also asked me for a recommendation.

All of this is really new to me because these kinds of things never happened to me in Zagreb. Sure, every now and then I would hear about an open position, but I didn't get the impression there was a constant demand for Software Engineers.

I'm really curious if all of this has just been a series of coincidences, or there really are a lot more open positions here. And if there are, I wonder what would be the right steps to take to make a similar atmosphere back home?
